tBYtUh8P.title: Fluvastatin decreases cardiac fibrosis possibly through regulation of TGF-β1/Smad 7 expression in the spontaneously hypertensive rats
tBYtUh8P.abstract: Statins ameliorate myocardial fibrosis after myocardial infarction. We designed this study to determine whether fluvastatin reduced hypertension-induced myocardial hypertrophy and fibrosis and whether these fluvastatin effects involved transforming growth factor β1 (TGF-β1) and Smad 7, factors known to play a role in the myocardial hypertrophy and fibrosis. We randomized 14 week old spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs) to receiving vehicle or 5–20 mg/kg/day fluvastatin for 8 weeks. Wistar Kyoto (WKY) rats receiving vehicle or 10 mg/kg/day fluvastatin were also studied. SHRs had an increased blood pressure, left ventricular hypertrophy and fibrosis compared with WKY rats. SHRs also had an elevated TGF-β1 expression and a decreased Smad 7 expression. These changes in SHRs were dose-dependently attenuated by fluvastatin. For example, the hydroxyproline content was 3.2 ± 0.1, 4.0 ± 0.1 and 3.5 ± 0.1 µg/mg heart and the Smad 7 protein expression was 5.1 ± 0.6, 1.0 ± 0.1 and 4.1 ± 0.7 arbitrary units for WKY rats, SHRs and SHRs receiving 20 mg/kg/day fluvastatin, respectively. The hydroxyproline content in the SHRs treated with or without fluvastatin was positively correlated with the left ventricular mass index, systolic blood pressure and the amount of TGF-β1 proteins and negatively correlated with the Smad 7 expression level. The left ventricular mass index was positively correlated with the systolic blood pressure. Fluvastatin did not alter the blood pressure, left ventricular mass index and collagen content of WKY rats. These results suggest that fluvastatin reduces hypertension-induced myocardial hypertrophy and fibrosis. These effects may involve an increased expression of Smad 7 and a decreased expression of TFG-β1. Our results call for clinical studies to evaluate these fluvastatin effects in hypertensive patients. Keywords Fibrosis Hypertension Hypertrophy Statin 1 Introduction Ventricular hypertrophy is an adaptive response to increased haemodynamic load and is identified as an independent risk factor of mortality for hypertensive patients ( Simko, 2002 ). Ventricular hypertrophy is manifested clinically as increase in the size and alteration in the shape and function of the heart ( Cohn et al., 2000 ). Histopathologically, it is characterized by cardiomyocyte hypertrophy, cardiac fibroblast proliferation and cell death ( Swynghedauw, 1999 ). These pathological processes can lead to cardiac fibrosis that is a result of disproportionate accumulation of extracellular matrix components, such as type I and type III collagen, in the heart. Cardiac fibrosis impedes both contraction and relaxation function and is arrhythmogenic ( Covell, 1990; Swynghedauw, 1999; Wu et al., 2004 ), indicating the role of anti-fibrosis therapy in improving cardiac functions. The 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase inhibitors, or so-called statins, reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in patients with high and moderate hypercholesterolemia or even normal cholesterol levels ( Sever et al., 2003 ). Recently, statins have been found to exert biological effects other than their cholesterol-lowering actions. These pleiotropic effects of statins include improvement of endothelial dysfunction, antioxidant properties, inhibition of inflammatory responses and stabilization of atherosclerotic plaques ( Davignon, 2004 ). Statins have also been shown to inhibit cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis. For example, simvastatin reduces human myofibroblast proliferation ( Porter et al., 2004 ). Atorvastatin attenuates the angiotensin II-induced collagen synthesis by rat or human cardiac fibroblasts ( Martin et al., 2005 ). Simvastatin also induces regression of cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis and improves cardiac function in a transgenic rabbit model of human hypertrophic cardiomyopathy ( Patel et al., 2001 ). Transforming growth factor-β1 (TGF-β1) is a powerful initiator for the synthesis of collagens and other major extracellular matrix components in many organ systems ( Khan and Sheppard, 2006 ). Evidence supports that TGF-β1, produced mainly by cardiac fibroblast and myofibroblast in the heart ( Eghbali, 1989 ), contributes to the development of cardiac fibrosis and hypertrophy ( Rosenkranz, 2004 ). It has been shown that the expression of TGF-β1 mRNA is increased in the left ventricular myocardium of patients with idiopathic hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or dilated cardiomyopathy and in animals after myocardial infarction ( Li et al., 1998; Pauschinger et al., 1999; Wang et al., 2002 ). Down-regulation of the TGF-β1 expression suppressed myocardial fibrosis ( Kawano et al., 2000 ). The TGF-β1 signaling can be transmitted through the Smad protein family ( Kretzschmar and Massague, 1998 ). Three groups of Smads have been identified ( Massague, 1990 ). The receptor-regulated Smads and common mediator Smad transduce the TGF-β1 signaling to cell nucleus. The inhibitory Smads can bind with the activated TGF-β1 receptors and prevent the signaling transduction through the receptor-regulated Smads and common mediator Smad ( Derynck and Zhang, 2003 ). Smad 7 is one of the inhibitory Smads and is expressed in the myocardium ( Wang et al., 2002 ). Defects in Smad 7 may lead to fibrotic conditions. Over-expression of Smad 7 in primary adult fibroblasts is associated with decreased type I and III collagen expression ( Wang et al., 2002 ). We designed this study to test the hypotheses that statins reduce hypertension-induced left ventricular hypertrophy and fibrosis and that these effects are mediated by regulating the expression of TGF-β1 and Smad 7. In this study, we administrated fluvastatin to spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs). We chose fluvastatin because it is a commonly used statin and has been shown to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality ( Ballantyne et al., 1999; Ribaut-Barassin et al., 2000 ). 2 Materials and methods The investigation conformed to the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals published by the US National Institutes of Health (NIH Publication No. 85-23, revised 1996) and was approved by the Animal Care and Use Committee of Sun Yat-Sen University. 2.1 Animals and fluvastatin treatment Twelve-week-old male SHRs and Wistar Kyoto (WKY) rats were purchased from Vital Riva (Beijing, China). Standard chow and water were provided ad libitum and the animals were maintained on a 12 h light/dark cycle. After a 2-week accommodation to the new environment, SHRs were randomly divided to receive 5, 10 or 20 mg/kg/day fluvastatin or the vehicle (distilled water) for 8 weeks. Rats were 22-week-old at the end of experiments. Fluvastatin (Novartis Pharmaceutical Company, China) was dissolved in distilled water. The drug or distilled water was administered orally by gavage once a day. The age-matched male WKY rats received distilled water or 10 mg/kg/day fluvastatin in the same way for 8 weeks. The systolic blood pressure was measured by tail-cuff method before and after the treatment. At the end of the study, the rats were anesthetized with an intraperitoneal injection of 10% chloral hydrate 3 ml/kg. Venous blood samples and hearts were harvested. The body weight and left ventricular mass were measured. The left ventricular mass index that is the ratio of left ventricular mass to body weight was calculated. The left ventricle, including the septum of the heart, was transversed into three parts: apex, middle ring and base that were put into a mixture of acetone and aether, 10% neutral formalin and liquid nitrogen, respectively, for further analysis. Venous blood samples from inferior vena cava were used for measurement of serum total cholesterol, triglyceride, low density lipoprotein-cholesterol (LDL-cholesterol), and high density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-cholesterol) by our central laboratories. 2.2 Hydroxyproline content assay Hydroxyproline was assayed using a procedure described previously ( Switzer, 1991 ). The apex of left ventricle was defatted and lysed. The sample was centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 10 min. The supernatant was mixed with fresh chloramine T for 10 min and then with Ehrlich's reagent at 75 °C for 20 min. After samples were cooled, optical density was read at 560 nm with a spectrophotometer that was adjusted by a blank. The blank was prepared by the same procedure but without cardiac tissues in the reaction mixture. Hydroxyproline concentration, expressed as micrograms per milligram of dry heart weight, was then calculated as described before ( Switzer, 1991 ). 2.3 Immunohistochemical analysis of collagen composition After fixed in 10% neutral formalin for 24 h, the middle ring of left ventricle was embedded in paraffin and cut into 4 μm thick sections. The section was incubated with primary antibodies [rabbit polyclonal anti-type I collagen antibody or anti-type III collagen antibody from Boster Biotect CO. (Wuhan, China) at a 1:150 dilution] at 4 °C overnight. Incubation with the secondary antibody (biotinylated goat anti-rabbit antibody also from Boster Biotect CO.) was performed at 37 °C for 30 min. Staining was generated with the streptavidin biotin–peroxidase complex immunohistochemical staining kit from Boster Biotect CO. Negative controls were performed by leaving out the primary antibody. Sections were viewed with 400× magnification and the intensity of the collagen staining was analyzed using the IBAS2.5 Image Analytical System (Institute of Biomedical Engineering, Beijing, China) as described before ( Sheng, 1995 ). Five random fields per section were analyzed to produce a single number for the section. 2.4 Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) analysis Semiquantification of the mRNA expressions of TGF-β1 and Smad 7 was performed by RT-PCR method. Total RNA was extracted from the base of left ventricle. One microgram of total RNA was subjected to the RT-PCR analyses using the RT-PCR High-Plus kit (Toyobo CO., Osaka, Japan). The forward primer and the reverse primer for rat TGF-β1, Smad 7 and β-actin were as follows: TGF-β1 forward, 5′-GAA GCC ATC CGT GGC CAG AT -3′; TGF-β1 reverse, 5′-CCA GTG ACG TCA AAA GAC AG-3′; Smad 7 forward, 5′-CCAACTGCAGACTGTCCAGA-3'; Smad 7 reverse, 5′-CAGGCTCCAGAAGAAGTTGG-3′; β-actin forward, 5′-CCT TCC TGG GTA TGG AAT CCT-3′; β-actin reverse, 5′-GGA GCA ATG ATC TTG ATC TT-3′. The bands were quantified densitometrically by a SynGene GeneGenius Bio Imaging System (Synoptics, Cambridge, UK). The results of TGF-β1 and Smad 7 were normalized by that of β-actin in the same sample. The data of WKY or SHRs in the fluvastatin treatment groups were then normalized by the mean value of SHRs in the vehicle control group. 2.5 Western blotting The base of left ventricle was used for Western analysis. Fifty micrograms of proteins were loaded for each lane. The primary antibodies were rabbit polyclonal anti-TGF-β1 or anti-Smad 7 antibodies from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc. (Santa Cruz, CA, USA) at a 1:200 dilution and rabbit polyclonal anti-β-actin from Boster Biotect CO. at a 1:400 dilution. The secondary antibody was goat anti-rabbit horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody from Cell Signaling Technology (Danvers, MA, USA) at a 1:4000 dilution. Bands were visualized by chemiluminescence detection and analyzed by the SynGene GeneGenius Bio Imaging System. The data of TGF-β1 and Smad 7 were normalized by the results of β-actin. The data of WKY or SHRs in the fluvastatin treatment groups were then normalized by the mean value of SHRs in the vehicle control group. 2.6 Statistical analysis Results are presented as means ± S.D. Each group has more than 6 animals. Differences in the data obtained before and after treatment in each group were compared by paired t tests. Differences in the data among the groups were compared by one-way ANOVA, followed by the Student–Newman–Keuls test. Correlation was assessed using a Pearson's correlation coefficient. P < 0.05 was considered significant. 3 Results 3.1 Effects of fluvastatin on serum lipid levels and systolic blood pressure We randomized 7 rats into each group. All rats except for one in the SHR vehicle control group survived at the end of the 8-week study. The data of the dead SHR were not included in the results presented in this paper. Table 1 summarizes the results of serum cholesterol and lipid levels at the end of the study. The serum cholesterol and lipid levels of WKY rats were not different from those of SHR control rats. Fluvastatin at 20 mg/kg/day significantly reduced the serum cholesterol of SHRs ( Table 1 ). The other lipid profiles were not affected by fluvastatin at the doses tested. Systolic blood pressure of SHRs was significantly higher than that of WKY rats. Fluvastatin at 10 and 20 mg/kg/day significantly reduced the systolic blood pressure of SHRs ( Table 2 ). The heart rates of SHRs were not different from those of WKY rats. Fluvastatin at any doses tested did not affect the heart rates ( Table 2 ). Fluvastatin at 10 m/kg/day did not alter the systolic blood pressure of WKY rats ( Table 2 ). 3.2 Fluvastatin attenuated cardiac hypertrophy of SHRs The body weights of SHRs were lower than those of age-matched WKY rats. Untreated SHRs showed left ventricular hypertrophy as reflected by the increased left ventricle mass and left ventricular mass index compared with WKY rats. Fluvastatin dose-dependently reduced the left ventricular mass and left ventricular mass index of the SHRs ( Table 3 ), suggesting that fluvastatin attenuated the progression of the left ventricular hypertrophy. Fluvastatin at 10 m/kg/day did not alter the left ventricular mass and left ventricular mass index of WKY rats ( Table 3 ). 3.3 Fluvastatin reduced cardiac fibrosis of SHRs Since myocardial fibrosis contributes to the pathology of ventricular hypertrophy ( Assayag et al., 1997; Rossi, 1998 ), we determined whether fluvastatin attenuated ventricular interstitial collagen deposition. As depicted in Fig. 1 , marked deposition of collagen I and collagen III was detected in the cardiac interstitial tissues of the SHRs compared with the WKY rats. This increased collagen deposition in the SHRs was dose-dependently ameliorated by fluvastatin. Consistent with the collagen deposition data, hydroxyproline content was elevated in the left ventricle of SHRs compared with WKY rats and this elevation was dose-dependently attenuated by fluvastatin ( Fig. 2 ). Hydroxyproline is mainly in the collagen in the mammalian proteins. Hydroxyproline content has been used as an indicator to reflect collagen amount in mammalian tissues. Thus, our results suggest that fluvastatin dose-dependently reduces left ventricular fibrosis in the SHRs. In contrast, 10 mg/kg/day fluvastatin did not change the collagen I, collagen III and hydroxyproline contents in the hearts of WKY rats ( Figs. 1 and 2 ). 3.4 Effects of fluvastatin on the expression of TGF-β1 and Smad 7 The expression of TGF-β1 mRNA and protein was increased in the left ventricles of SHRs compared with WKY rats. This increase was dose-dependently reduced by fluvastatin ( Figs. 3 and 4 ). Interestingly, the expression of Smad 7 mRNA and protein in the left ventricles of SHRs was lower than that of WKY rats. Fluvastatin dose-dependently increased the mRNA and protein expression of Smad 7 in the left ventricles of the SHRs ( Figs. 3 and 4 ). Fluvastatin at 10 mg/kg/day did not change the expression of Smad 7 and TGF-β1 in the left ventricles of the WKY rats ( Figs. 3 and 4 ). 3.5 Relationship among blood pressure, cardiac fibrosis and hypertrophy and contribution of TGF-β1 and Smad 7 to cardiac fibrosis The pooled data from all SHRs treated with or without fluvastatin showed that the hydroxyproline content was significantly correlated with the left ventricular mass index ( Fig. 5 A ), suggesting that the reduced cardiac interstitial fibrosis by fluvastatin contributes to the decreased left ventricular mass index by this drug in SHRs. The hydroxyproline content was also significantly correlated with the systolic blood pressure in the SHRs ( Fig. 5 B), indicating that the reduced interstitial fibrosis by fluvastatin may involve the reduction of systolic blood pressure by this drug. The left ventricular mass index was correlated with the systolic blood pressure ( Fig. 5 C), suggesting that the reduction of blood pressure by fluvastatin contributes to its attenuation of cardiac hypertrophy. The reduced cardiac fibrosis by fluvastatin may be mediated by the increased expression of Smad 7 and decreased TGF-β1 expression because the hydroxyproline content was negatively correlated with the Smad 7 protein expression and was positively correlated with the TGF-β1 protein expression ( Fig. 5 D and E). 4 Discussion Hypertension is a common disease and can cause cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis, the major determinants of morbidity and mortality from cardiovascular diseases ( Assayag et al., 1997; Haider et al., 1998 ). The present study showed that fluvastatin reduced blood pressure, the left ventricular hypertrophy and myocardial fibrosis in the SHRs. These beneficial pleiotropic effects of fluvastatin may have an important implication in clinical medicine. Cardiac hypertrophy and interstitial fibrosis are common responses to cardiac injury and overload ( Cohn et al., 2000; Simko, 2002 ). It has been suggested that about two thirds of myocardial cells are fibroblasts and that they are responsible for the production and deposition of the majority of extracellular matrix proteins that mainly include fibronectins, vitronectins and collagens ( Grove et al., 1969; Khan and Sheppard, 2006 ). Collagen I accounts for 80% of total collagen newly synthesized from these cells and the other 20% of the collagen is collagen III ( Bashey et al., 1992 ). Multiple stimulations, including static stretch of the cells, can promote fibroblast cell proliferation and collagen synthesis ( Weber and Brilla, 1991 ). Statins, including fluvastatin, were developed to reduce serum lipid levels. However, these drugs have many beneficial pleiotropic effects, such as improvement of endothelial dysfunction, antioxidant properties and inhibition of inflammatory responses ( Davignon, 2004 ). The reduced cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis by fluvastatin as shown in this study may not be due to its lipid-lowering effects because 10 mg/kg/day fluvastatin did not change any lipid profile but reduced cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis in SHRs. In addition, SHRs had lipid levels comparable to WKY rats but had cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis compared with WKY rats. The beneficial cardiac effects of fluvastatin may involve its effects on the blood pressure. Our study showed that fluvastatin reduced systolic blood pressure of SHRs. The hydroxyproline content was positively correlated with the systolic blood pressure. The left ventricular mass index was also positively correlated with the systolic blood pressure. These results suggest that the reduction of blood pressure by fluvastatin may contribute to its attenuation of cardiac fibrosis. Statins have been shown to reduce blood pressure in SHRs ( Sicard et al., 2005 ). Conflicting evidence regarding whether statins have hypotensive effects in humans is provided by early studies ( Glorioso et al., 1999; Muramatsu et al., 1997 ). Recent studies have shown that statins decrease blood pressure of patients with hypertension but do not affect blood pressure in normotensive patients ( Ferrier et al., 2002; Sever et al., 2003; Terzoli et al., 2005 ). Consistent with these human data, we show that fluvastatin decreases blood pressure in SHRs but not in WKY rats. Thus, decreasing blood pressure in hypertensive animals and human may be one of the pleiotropic effects of Statins. Statins have been shown to improve endothelial dysfunction and increase nitric oxide bioavailability under various pathological conditions ( Davignon, 2004; Mason et al., 2004 ). These effects may be the underlying mechanisms for statins to decrease blood pressure. The mechanisms underlying cardiac fibrosis in hypertensive heart are not fully understood. Available evidence suggests that activation of the rennin–angiotensin–aldosterone system and the increased pressure load contribute to the pathological process. Angiotensin II, by activating its downstream molecules including TGF-β1 and aldosterone, is fibrogenic ( Johar et al., 2006; Lijnen and Petrov, 2000; Ramires et al., 1998; Rosenkranz, 2004 ). Pressure overload stretches fibroblast cells, which can promote collagen synthesis ( Weber and Brilla, 1991 ). Reduction of blood pressure by fluvastatin should decrease the cardiac load and stretch and the activation of the rennin–angiotensin–aldosterone system and should subsequently attenuate the left ventricular hypertrophy and fibrosis. One of the pleiotropic effects of stains is anti-inflammatory effects ( Davignon, 2004 ). The proinflammatory cytokines, such as interleukin-1β, can promote cardiac inflammation, fibrosis and hypertrophy ( Hinglais et al., 1994; Shioi et al., 1997 ). Statins reduce the expression of proinflammatory cytokines under various pathological conditions including high-salt diet-induced cardiac hypertrophy in Dahl rats ( Hasegawa et al., 2003; Yu et al., 2004 ). Thus, the anti-inflammatory effects of fluvastatin may contribute to the reduction of the ventricular hypertrophy and fibrosis in our study. To determine the cellular factors that mediate the fluvastatin-induced reduction of left ventricular hypertrophy and fibrosis in the SHR, we focused on the TGF-β1 expression. It has been shown that hypertrophic stimuli, such as increased cardiac load, increase the expression of TGF-β1 in the cardiomyocytes and myocardial fibroblasts ( Takahashi et al., 1994 ). TGF-β1 can then induce cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis by regulating cell differentiation and growth and stimulating the synthesis and deposition of the extracellular matrix components, such as collagens. Studies have implicated the importance of TGF-β1 during the development of ventricular hypertrophy and fibrosis in hypertensive hearts ( Kuwahara et al., 2002; Rosenkranz et al., 2002 ). Angiotensin II, a peptide that contributes significantly to the pathology of hypertensive hearts, induces the expression of TGF-β1 to cause cardiac hypotrophy and fibrosis ( Campbell and Katwa, 1997; Schultz et al., 2002; Tokuda et al., 2004 ). We showed here that SHRs had an increased expression of TGF-β1 and cardiac hypotrophy and fibrosis compared with WKY rats, that fluvastatin treatment reduced the expression of TGF-β1 in the left ventricles of SHRs and that the cardiac fibrosis was positively correlated to the expression of TGF-β1 in those rats. Thus, our results suggest that fluvastatin reduces the expression of TGF-β1 to attenuate the cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis in the SHRs. TGF-β1 binds and activates its receptors ( Massague, 1990 ). The activated TGF-β1 receptor phosphorylates the receptor-regulated Smads (R-Smads: Smad 2 and Smad 3). Activated R-Smads form heteromeric complexes with Smad 4, the common mediator Smad. These complexes then translocate to the nucleus, where they interact with transcription factors, co-activators and co-repressors to control gene expression ( Kretzschmar and Massague, 1998; Labbe et al., 1998 ). Smad 7, an inhibitory Smad, can form a stable binding complex with the activated TGF-β receptor. This binding prevents the receptor activation of R-Smads ( Derynck and Zhang, 2003 ). It has been shown that the reduced Smad 7 expression contributes to the development of cardiac fibrosis in rats after myocardial infarction ( Wang et al., 2002 ). In the present study, the Smad 7 expression level in the heart of SHRs is lower than that in the heart of WKY rats. SHRs had cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis. Our results, along with the data showing the role of Smad 7 in the cardiac fibrosis after infarction ( Wang et al., 2002 ), suggest that the reduced Smad 7 expression contributes to the hypertensive cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis. This suggestion is strengthened by our findings that fluvastatin increased the Smad 7 expression and reduced the left ventricular hypertrophy and fibrosis and that the Smad 7 protein expression is negatively correlated with the hydroxyproline content in the hearts of SHRs. The expression of Smad 7 can be induced by TGF-β1 ( Landstrom et al., 2000; Wang et al., 2002 ). This forms an autoregulatory negative feedback loop to regulate the TGF-β1 signaling. However, SHRs had an increased TGF-β1 expression and a decreased Smad 7 expression. A similar expression pattern of TGF-β1 and Smad 7 was found in rat hearts after infarction, although the expression of both TGF-β1 and Smad 7 was increased transiently within a few hours after the infarction ( Wang et al., 2002 ). It was proposed that persistent increase of TGF-β1 expression may decrease the expression of Smad 7 in viable cardiac tissues and that this effect may not be necessary through the TGF-β1 signaling per se ( Wang et al., 2002 ). Indeed, the expression of Smad 7 can be regulated by other factors, such as interferon-γ ( Ulloa et al., 1999 ). Our results showed that fluvastatin treatment reduced the TGF-β1 expression and increased Smad 7 expression in the SHRs. The mechanisms for these effects are not known. Statins have been shown to block the synthesis of various isoprenoid intermediates, such as geranyl pyrophosphate and farnesyl pyrophosphate, that play a critical role in the activation of small GTP-binding proteins, including Rho, Ras, and Rac, through their isoprenylation and may work as lipid attachments for their post-translational modification ( Davignon, 2004 ). A broad range of intracellular signaling pathways may then be modified by statins. In conclusion, fluvastatin decreased hypertension-induced cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis. These effects may not involve its lipid-lowering effects and may be mediated by its blood pressure-lowering effects. The cellular responses for these beneficial effects may involve down-regulation of the TGF-β1 expression and up-regulation of Smad 7 expression. Clinical studies should be set up to evaluate these beneficial effects of fluvastatin in the hypertensive patients. o2TTRKb7.title: Multi-stage cold forging process for H68 brass cylindrical shell part with deep blind hole: simulation and experiment
o2TTRKb7.abstract: The classical manufacture technology of H68 brass cylindrical shell part with deep blind hole is machining process, which can achieve requirements of dimension precision, but the process has lower efficiency, and the strength and toughness of the parts do not satisfy the usage requirements in the industry. The multi-stage cold forging process, which could improve the mechanical properties of the parts, is used to replace the traditional machining process. The process designs of multi-stage cold forging process for parts have been studied, including several operations such as annealing, initial upsetting, preforming, back extrusion, ironing, and upsetting flange. In order to ensure the multi-stage cold forging process, one finite element (FE) simulation, used to study strain distributions and flow lines, is conducted. Based on the FE results, several cold forging dies have been designed and manufactured. The experimental work shows that the cold work-hardening effect is obtained, and distribution of flow lines is reasonable; precision accuracy and mechanical properties meet the technical requirements, and production efficiency has been improved significantly.

SI1TTnDq.title: Integrated Voltage and Power Flow Management Considering the Cost of Opera in Active Distribution Networks
SI1TTnDq.abstract: The increasing penetration of distributed energy resources on the distribution networks have brought a number of technical impacts where voltage and thermal variations have been identified as the dominant effects. Active network management in distribution networks aims to integrate distributed energy resources with flexible network management so that distributed energy resources are organized to make better use of existing capacity and infrastructure. This paper propose active solutions which aims to solve the voltage and thermal issues in a distributed manner utilizing a collaborative approach. The proposed algorithms have been fully tested on a distribution network with distributed generation units.

TCO7SCIU.title: Effect of nano-TiO2/EP composite coating on dynamic characteristics of surface charge in epoxy resin
TCO7SCIU.venue: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation

6ACM4l9u.title: The control mechanism of micron and nano SiO2/epoxy composite coating on surface charge in epoxy resin
6ACM4l9u.abstract: Charge accumulation on the surface of epoxy resin affects the insulation performance under DC voltage. In order to illustrate the effect of surface coating on the characteristics of surface charge accumulation in epoxy resin, micron and nano SiO 2 /epoxy composite coatings were deposited on the surface of epoxy resin by spraying, and the charge accumulation on the surface was studied by the electrostatic probe method. The surface trap parameters were analyzed by the method of isothermal surface potential decay combining with the carrier mobility and cross-section morphology of samples, the transport characteristics of surface charge and the respective control mechanism of coating layer were studied. The results suggest that the surface charge mainly accumulates near the electrodes, the main source of charges is injected from the electrodes. The surface charges near the anode are caused by charge trapping, and the surface charges near the cathode are caused by the adsorption due to the normal electric field. Surface charge accumulation can be suppressed by increasing the shallow trap density and carrier mobility on the surface of material, which is available by coating with micron and nano SiO 2 /epoxy composites. It was found that, surface charge of epoxy resin could be suppressed effectively by coating of micron SiO 2 particles with content of 1~3 wt%, or nano SiO 2 particles with content of 3 wt%.
